captions.text: Our sun and the earth, and all the planets and moons and dwarf planets
and asteroids and comets... The Solar System in short
formed about 4.6 billion years ago from a nebulous cloud
of swirling gas and dust which coalesced thanks to the irresistibly

attractive force of gravity.
of swirling gas and dust which coalesced thanks to the irresistibly
attractive force of gravity.
However, theis nebula started off more or less as a big shapeless blob
So how did our solar system end up with all the planets
and their moons orbiting in a flat disk?
I mean, we've all seen the planetary model of the atom,
which is definitely wrong when applied to atoms
but it also kind of suggests that planets might revolve
around the sun every which way.
So is our solar system somehow special in its flatness?
Or is the planetary model of the atom doubly wrong?
Well, our solar system definitely isn't alone,
many exoplanets' star systems are flat,
a lot of galaxies are flat,
black hole accretion disks are flat,
Saturn's rings are flat,
etc.
So why, when there's all of 3D space to fill,
does the universe have this preference for flatness?
The answer has to do with two things? collisions
and the fact that we live in three dimensions.
Bear with me.
Anytime a bunch of objects held together by gravity are zooming and circling around
their individual paths are nearly impossible to predict,
and yet, collected together they have a single total amount
that they spin about their center of mass.
It may be hard to figure out exactly what direction that rotation is in
but the mathematics implies there must be some plane
in which the cloud -taken as a whole- spins.
Now, in two dimensions a cloud of particles rotating in a plane
is flat by definition, it's in two dimensions.
But in three dimensions, even though the rotation of the cloud is given
by one plane, particles can whiz around far up and down from that plane.
As the particles bump into each other, all the up and down motion
tends to cancel out. It's energy lost in crashing and clumping.
Yet the whole mass must continue spinning inexorably,
because in our universe, the total amount of spinning in any isolated system
always stays the same.
So over time through collisions and crashes, the cloud loses its loft
and flattens into a spinning, roughly 2 dimensional disk shape, like a solar system or a spiral galaxy.
However, in 4 spacial dimensions, the math works out such that
there can be two separate and complementary planes of rotation
which is both really really hard for our 3D-thinking brains to picture
and also means there's no up and down direction in which particles lose energy by collisions.
So a cloud of particles can continue being just that... a cloud.
And thus, only in three dimensions can a nebula or infant galaxy
start out not flat and end up flat
which is definitely a good thing because we need all that matter to clump together
in order for stars and planets to form, and for us,
-even those of us who think atoms look like this-
to exist.

title: Why is the Solar System Flat?

comments.text:
If a massive herd of animals is running around in a BIG BIG circle and 
you're "intending" to run through that herd of animals, there is probably 
no way that you're going to make it through without getting hit by an 
animal, therefore when you go through that herd of animals, they will run 
into you and change your direction so that your direction of travel is the 
same as the direction that they are heading in.

So, with all of the "space dust" and larger pieces of mass that begin 
spinning around a centre point of gravity (In space), there will be an 
"established" route which the particles will take when orbiting around the 
centre. And eventually all of the *other* particles which are under the 
gravitational influence of the sun but haven't yet joined the main route *will 
eventually* collide with (and join) the particles that are already taking 
the main route and they will become part of the flow of the main route.
And basically it's probably gonna look like a flat plane.﻿

If magnets pull something towards itself, but I spin it all around (not 
possible to do as an experiment physically but you get the idea) and the 
matters have a too high mass for the magnet to bring it closer but it still 
keeps it from flying away, the matters that are spinning around the magnet 
will spin around in the same disc shape all the time. This is pure physical 
balance between the two. "But how come all of the matters spin in the same 
disc dimension?" Well, I wouldn't say I'm an expert in physics (I've 
forgotten much of what I once learned), but my bet would have to be the 
magnet's magnetic field. And if you know enough about electro-physics and 
astro physics, you'd know that the magnetic field is not just a ball shaped 
shell, it's more like an tall donut... which could then be the reason.﻿

comments.text:
+Feynstein100 A collision between molecules is caused by electrostatic 
repulsion. Collisions transfer momentum. That is what I mean by 
electromagnetism.
comments.author: Tony Spilotro

comments.text:
+Tony Spilotro
 What does electromagnetism have to do with transfer of momentum?
comments.author: Feynstein100

comments.text:
+Feynstein100 A gas cloud, mostly hydrogen, will start to gravitationally 
collapse, as it does so the gas will be compressed. The gas starts to 
electromagnetically interact. This involves ionization, radiation, but 
mostly the transfer of momentum. This transfer of momentum from the inside 
of the collapsing gas cloud to the outside eventually flattens the gas 
cloud into a disk.
If particles did not interact electromagnetically then there would not be a 
transfer of angular momentum and the particles would stay in a spherical 
distribution as they collapsed. This is what happens to dark matter. 
Gravitation and electromagnetism are both important in forming solar 
systems.
comments.author: Tony Spilotro

comments.text:
+Tony Spilotro
How is electromagnetism the cause of collisions?
comments.author: Feynstein100

comments.text:
+Feynstein100 Well, there are 2 major forces that sculpt flat star systems 
and galaxies. Electromagnetism is the cause of the collisions. Dark matter 
on the other hand only interacts gravitationally.

comments.author: Stuart Hull

comments.text:
+Stuart Hull Your explanation MAY hold for Solar Systems but doesn't seem 
to hold for Galaxies.  I quote "In computer simulations of our galaxy, the 
Milky Way, theorists found that the center would not hold—based on what we 
can see of it, our galaxy doesn’t have enough mass to keep everything in 
place."  Gravity does not seem to be the binding force behind Galaxies and 
from many scientists doesn't completely hold true for many objects at the 
outer limits of our own Solar System.  There is still much we don't know 
and it seems ludicrous not to ask.  Just asking new questions can lead to 
new answers.
comments.author: Pecker Wood

comments.text:
+Pecker Wood In solar systems and galaxies the material maintains orbital 
velocity so it has no tendency to fall closer to the center. It can 
therefore flatten out. However the material in the Earth is nowhere near 
orbital velocity so it falls until it collides with the Earth, where it 
gets stuck to the outside. 

Think of it like this: a flat disk-shaped Earth would be supported by the 
rock it is made of, because gravity wants to compress it. This rock is far 
too thin to handle the huge weight and pressure so the entire thing 
collapses to put as much mass as close to the center as possible: a ball. 


Conversely in a galactic plane the material is in orbit so it's 
gravitational pull is counterracted by the centrifugal force (correct usage 
in this frame of reference) so the material doesn't move closer to the 
center. To create this balance, however, it must be moving quickly, so 
collisions occur and the video shows the mathematics behind the disk shape.
comments.author: Stuart Hull

comments.author: Zaron728

comments.text:
+Pecker Wood "I think the theory is still incomplete, otherwise planets and 
suns would look like discs as well."

The particles in a Star or planet are rammed up against one another. They 
are perpetually crashing into each other and are held up by: electrostatic 
forces (planets/moons), the pressure of nuclear fusion (for a normal star), 
electron degeneracy pressure (white dwarf), or neutron degeneracy pressure 
(neutron star). None of these effects tend to make an object into a disc.

A solar system's planets, comets, and other objects are not held up by any 
of the effects above. They are kept from collapsing into the central mass 
by angular momentum (like a space craft is when it orbits the Earth). 
Angular moment does tend to shape an object like a disc like the video said.

In fact stars, planets, and other large spinning objects are actually 
something in between a disc and a sphere. The effect of angular momentum 
holding up the stuff on Earth is very small compared to the electrostatic 
forces because the Earth for its mass and radius isn't spinning fast 
enough. The Earth and the Sun are "oblate spheroids."

You can really say that most stuff in space tends to form into a disk, a 
sphere, or something in the middle an oblate spheroid. In fact no perfect 
sphere or disk will ever exist so almost everything is an "oblate spheroid" 
and tends to go to that shape overtime. How spherical or disk like depends 
on the mass, radius, and angular momentum of the system. 

"Conversely, why do neutron stars and black holes eject energy 
perpendicular to their plane of axis."

Well an object falling into a blackhole accelerates like nothing else. 
Objects close to the event horizon are going close to the speed of light 
but just a little further out they are moving substantially slower. The 
matter that doesn't fall directly into the hole orbits it very fast 
(because it has angular momentum) and it gets torn apart by all the 
friction caused by running into other very fast things or things moving at 
different speeds. This creates a plasma and a whole bunch of charged 
particles flying around in a circle close to the speed of light (atoms 
contain charged particles but the collisions tear atoms apart). The 
interaction creates a magnetic field with the north and south poles of the 
field roughly in the same place as the north and south poles of the 
rotating blackhole (because the rotating charges create the field). Some of 
these super high speed particles follow the field lines in two jets 
creating huge amounts of gamma/x-ray/particle radiation. The charges 
spiraling around magnetic field lines is a property of the magnetic field 
(explained using relativity). The charges would also want to spin around in 
the magnetic field in opposite directions (also a property of magnetism). 
This same effect explains why Auroras happen at the magnetic poles. In the 
Aurora's case the charged particles from the Sun follow the field lines 
back to the poles. In a blackhole they'd get swept up into the magnetic 
field then explosively jet out. Solar flares also spiral charged plasma 
around field lines then eject it into space.

Blackholes because they are so small compared to their mass should spin 
very fast (like an ice skater bringing her arms in to spin faster) creating 
a very large magnetic field when charged particles are spinning in the 
accretion disk. The poles will build up energy and snap like a solar flares 
creating huge jets at the poles.

I tried to post this on a relevant video but the comments were off.

We see stars, from earth, as the star was X years ago. The further away a 
star, the further "back" we're seeing. It follows, then, that being right 
next to the star means we'll see it as it was Y seconds ago.

My question is if we got in an impossibly fast spaceship and went straight 
at the star, looking out a window at the star, would we see the star behave 
in a fast forward kind of way, as we catch up from X years ago to Y seconds 
ago in a matter of time less than X-Y?

My instinct says yes, of course it'll arrears to accelerate. It isn't 
really accelerating but we're playing the photon filmstrip in fast forward 
so to speak. But I think I remember hearing about some quirk of relativity 
that blows this idea up.

Which is it?﻿

comments.author: Room 641A

comments.text:
There aren't nearly enough things orbiting the nucleus in an atom to 
balance out the net angular momentum. This is due to Pauli's Exclusion 
Principle, which says that two fermions (like electrons) won't have the 
same quantum state. It's also because of the fact that atoms are best 
described using quantum physics, while solar systems can be described 
classically because they are larger. In addition, the electromagnetic force 
will keep the charged particles from colliding, if we look at it 
classically.

disk (meaning other planets/debris are minutely out of alignment to 
compensate).

comments.author: Oswald “Osvis” Lit

comments.text:
Atoms don't really have a shape. But you could attribute them a 3d-shape, 
using the concept of orbitals. Orbitals are special regions where electrons 
(^^) are likely to be found (as they are quantum objects, you can't define 
an exact orbit around the nucleus of the atom, only a probability where it 
might be) . If you arrange these orbitals around the nucleus you have an 
idea how to think of the atom. As an example, this is the orbital-structure 
of a neon atom:
http://newscenter.lbl.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2012/01/neon-orbitals.jpg
